Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 05:58PM bluesky wrote: there will be no drains if they do not remove nodes.
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 06:35PM bluesky wrote: a core biopsy would not miss cancer, this is the standard practice now a days, but you should do what feels best for you, i did not want to have so many surgerys, i find them very invasive, the core needle biopsy for me was easy to endure.
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 05:42PM bluesky wrote: kim-yes they put in a drain after lumpectomy, the drain is there for one week and then your surgeon will remove it. you should not be doing any heavy lifting, especially if they are doing lymph node removal, if you do continual heavy lifting all day every day this will bring on lymphadema. in terms of time off work, i took 2 weeks off, i had to use vacation time as i had only been at the job for 6 months. if you have been there more than one year, you should look into the medical leave act policy for your company and state. i think you need at least 2 weeks after surgery to recover.
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: Apr 19, 2008 05:57PM bluesky wrote: kim-oh ok, mine was done differently they did a biopsy first to determine if it was cancer or b9, once we had the confirmation that it was bc, the surgeon performed the lumpectomy with sentinel node biopsy, this means that they test the first node for cancer, mine was positive therefore they removed 18 lymph nodes. you should question your doctor, about a biopsy first this will save you from having an extra surgery, if it god forbid turns out to be bc, this means they will need to do another surgery to test lymph nodes if it's invasive bc, if it's dcis then they would not need to test nodes.
Posts.Title: Drains & Time Off Work For Lumpectomy Kim32 Solihull

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2008 01:25PM bluesky wrote: hpellerin-i know it's hard but try not to freak out. i'm not clear on your situation? but when fear sets in try to remember that 80% of lumps/nodules are benign. they are being super thourough and that's really good. the waiting is indeed the hardest part, but friday will get here soon. whatever you do don't go on line and start researching, i did this and drove myself nuts and made myself consumed with fear. hang in there and whatever it is you will get thru it. keep us posted. be well. try to meditate and use the mantra i am totally healthy.

Posts.Title: Pet Scans and Bone Scans after Treatment bluesky amlg1

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 05:28PM bluesky wrote: Hi Bejuce, I did not get any scans after I finished the treatments, they only did them before I started. I don't think there is any need to do them unless there is reason to, such as; increase in blood work tumor markers, pain, or any lumps. This is also what my Oncologist and Breast Surgeon told me.  It's best to consult with you doctor on this.
Posts.Title: Pet Scans and Bone Scans after Treatment bluesky amlg1

Posts.Content: bluesky wrote: I finished all my treatments-chemo, radiation in April 2007, I had 2 lumpectomies and am now on tamoxifen for 5 years, I initially had all the pet scans and bone scan and thankfully all was clear, I have two visits a year with my Oncologist and my Surgeon I get a bilateral breast MRI and Ultrasound once a year, my bloodwork is done twice a year and they check the tumor markers. I have not had any scans since 2006 because my doctors said that they don't do them unless there is reason to.   I want to know how many of you have done yearly scans, to check things out?  Or were you told the same thing I was? Dx 10/25/2006, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 4/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Pet Scans and Bone Scans after Treatment bluesky amlg1

Posts.Content: May 4, 2008 06:44AM bluesky wrote: i too was very very scared and terrified, i went from being stage 1 to 3a, it has been 1.5 years and day by day i feel better, i have met many ladies with many lymph nodes involved who had it years ago and are doing great, one lady had 10 nodes involved 20 years ago and she is doing great. as everyone has already said follow the doctors tx, if you are into alternative tx when you are done with chemo, you can see a holistic breast cancer specialist who will help build your immune system to the strongest level as well as accupunture, yoga, good diet, exercise these all helped me very much.
Posts.Title: Prognosis? dcjoslin56 florencedonna

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2008 07:05PM bluesky wrote: sofeemay-i am so sorry to hear about everything that you have been thru, truly too much. sending you lot's of hugs, i hope and pray that the biopsy is benign, i don't know how they do it? rest, sleep and eat really well. lots of veggetables; key ones that contain alot of iron and antioxidants are artichokes, broccolli, kale, spinach, beets, protein, fish, chicken, and plenty of fruits; blueberries are the richest form of antioxadant, raspberries, strawberries are good too. if you can get accupuncture and see a homeopathic, breast cancer specialist to combine traditional and natural healing. take care, and again i hope and pray you get b9 results.
Posts.Title: ct shows lung mets-but biopsy on tuesday sofeemay faeriesong

Posts.Content: bluesky wrote: My last chemo treatment was April 3, 2007, I have been on Tamoxifen for 3 years and went into menopause after 2nd chemo treatment.  Most days I feel good, however every week or sometimes every other week I experience days in which I am in a foggy state, with mild memory loss, sometimes difficulty comprehending things that I am reading or conversations that I am listening to. I also at times feel off balance and overcome with anxiety. Lately I have been more stressed than usual due to job loss and I'm wondering if this has something to do with it along with the chemo brain or is it the tamoxifen or menopause or all of the above?  It's so frustrating because I was very not like this prior to chemo.   Is anyone else experiencing this?   Dx 10/25/2006, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 4/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Foggy Brain-3 Years After Chemo Treatment bluesky Joviangeldeb

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2010 12:25AM bluesky wrote: lamuso-I brought up the chemo brain to my oncologist while I was going thru the treatment and he said that it was normal and would eventually repair itself. I have not brought it up again as approximately 6 months after chemo I was making progress and my memory, comprehension, loss of words, seemed to be improving over the last 2 years, but in the last few months it seems to have reverted back a little, I am very stressed out about it, because I am looking for work and really need to be at my best.......It is a known fact that chemo decreases brain function,  I read that the brain eventually can repair itself, I read this 3.5 years ago written by Japanese scientists in a NY Times article.  ordinary mammal-Thank you so much for all the info, I'm going to get this book and start researching all that I can to help myself improve this situation.  It is very upsetting because I used to be very witty, sharp at grasping things and had a great memory, short and long term, I know some of it is aging I'm going to be 46 in October, but still this is too much for 46......I won't accept this.  But I do have to say at times I'm just so overwhelmed by it all, I'm grateful to be healthy, but it's been such a long road, I still have 25 pounds to lose, a disfigured breast, and now the mind.............It's really too much sometimes...((
Posts.Title: Foggy Brain-3 Years After Chemo Treatment bluesky Joviangeldeb

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2008 10:07PM bluesky wrote: good idea to choose cleaning the margin, i think most of the time they get everything the second time in and it is very common for positive margins. also good not to focus on the numbers, the doctors are not god and they are only going by stats and every human is different. hang in there, there will be light at the end of this dark tunnel and you will be fine. take care. franca
Posts.Title: Path report back--Licking my wounds dibel bluesky

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2008 07:51PM bluesky wrote: hi dibel, i was diagnosed october 2006, and was told the tumor was part dcis, and that the chance that it had spread to the lymph nodes were 10%, i was stage 1, after the lumpoctemy they found that it spread to 4 lymph nodes and the margins were not clean, i was stage 3, i was horrified, how could i go from stage 1 to stage 3, i was in depair for 4 weeks, the second surgery went very well, the margins were clean and the only reason i was categorized as stage 3 was by one lymph node, which the surgeon did not explain to me and i was so focussed on the staging, then i started to focus on the positive and made it through the treatments, 1 and half years later, i'm feeling better and i am only struggling with lingering fatigue and weight gain. i wish you all of the best and may god bless you! take care and be well. by the way, i am a yoga teacher and did yoga throughout which helped me very much with the healing process. franca
Posts.Title: Path report back--Licking my wounds dibel bluesky

(sorry to have to say that) i also think your mothers comment is crazy and she is not comprehending this.

Posts.Content: bluesky wrote: I have been on Tamoxifen for 3 years, I recently asked my Oncologist if after 5 years of Tamoxifen I had to take other medicine and he said maybe because I was put into menopause by Chemo in January 2007.  The SE of Tamoxifen have been very difficult for me, especially the weight gain, between chemo and tamoxifen I have gained 40 pounds, I lost 13 pounds last year but had to work very hard to lose the weight, I have not been able to lose the balance of the 30 pounds that I gained and it is driving me crazy, I was a very fit, healthy slim person before BC, the last 4 years have been extremely tough, and the thought of having to take another pill after 5 years of Tamoxifen is really depressing me.  How many of you had to take another pill after Tamoxifen? Dx 10/25/2006, IDC, 2cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 4/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: After 5 Years of Tamoxifen, Another Pill? bluesky Member_of_the_Club

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2008 05:03PM bluesky wrote: pipersmama-i'm so sorry you are going thru this, i know it's very scary, but do all that you can to stay in the present moment and don't get ahead, also i highly recommend that you do not google for any other info, i did that and i made my self sick and so stressed. focus on right now each moment and try to get thru the weekend, if you can do some meditation, yoga. waiting is the hardest part as is controlling your mind and not letting it runaway and invent all of these scary scenarios. 80% of lumps are b9, focus on this for now. they must do the biopsy in order to find out what it is, this is standard now a days. good luck and come back here often for help in getting thru the weekend. take care
Posts.Title: Worried, worried, worried pipersmama RedWeasel

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2008 12:20PM bluesky wrote: egal-the same thing happened to me, i did not know that radiation could damage the thyroid, when chemo ended i kept putting on weight and was very very tired, they checked my thyroid and it was not working properly, i've been working with an endroconolgist for five months to get the right dose, still not there. by the way it takes over a year to feel better after chemo, my oncy told me within eight weeks i would have 80% of my energy back, that was a lie! i felt pretty s***ty for over a year, i still don't feel great and it's been one year. i don't know if it's the tamoxifen or the synthroid, but i do not feel like i did before all of this, everyone keeps telling me to give it time......anyway i hope you feel better soon.
Posts.Title: Radiation Damaged My Thyroid Katiejane paige-allyson

Posts.Content: bluesky wrote: On October 25th it was 4 years that I have been NED, I know I should be happy, but I am not, I stopped Tamoxifen after 3 1/2 years, due to extreme side effects and I'm am afraid of not taking it, but am also afraid taking it, so I'm miserable over this.  I have put on 35 pounds since the DX, and I can't get it off, I lost 13 pounds but put half of it back on.  I have been unemployed for 1 year and I may have a job offer with a past employer, but am too embarrassed to see him, because of the weight gain, I work in the fashion industry and he is so shallow and I'm afraid he will say something or may not hire because of it.  I used to be slim and fit and very good looking, now I can't even look in the mirror.  I just can't seem to get passed all of this.  BC has destroyed my life.  I'm numb, sad, depressed, afraid and constantly tired.  I don't see a light and I just keep crying. Posts.Title: WISHES (WHAT DO YOU WISH FOR) lizzie5308 lizzie5308

Posts.Content: May 1, 2008 06:10PM bluesky wrote: marylynn-for a tumor that is less than 1cm, a radical mx is extremely aggressive. lumpectomy and mx have the same outcome. i know women who have had bi lateral mx and mx and it still came back, what is meant to be will be. i'm a big worrier too, i was 42 when dx, i went with the lumpectomy and feel good about my decision. if you are having second thoughts it sounds like you are not ready to go thru with this, talk it very thoroughly with your doctors.
Posts.Title: Not sure what to do. MaryLynn Shirlann

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2008 08:16PM bluesky wrote: bcs75-i know how you feel, it is terrifing! i felt the exact same way, i too had a lumpectomy and a spot showed up on my left lung on the same side as surgery, they checked it again 6 months later and no change, it was just fluid and scaring from the surgery. also keep in mind that the scans are known to show a lot of false positives, meaning they pick every little speck and most of the times it is nothing. as your oncologist said, it would be highly unlikely that it metastized so quickly. i too had 4 positive nodes with a high grade tumor and everything turned out to be fine. focus on all the positive info and when the mind wanders bring it back to clean scans. let us know the outcome. sending you positive vibes and prayers.
Posts.Title: possible lung mets bcs75 Dukemom2
